tuv.prop: <seg>It is also the largest of the Solar System's four terrestrial planets.</seg>
tuv.seg: Earth is the third planet, and the densest and fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System.
Земля - третья Планета от Солнца, и плотные и пятое место из восьми планет Солнечной Системы.

tuv.prop: <seg>Earth is the third planet from the Sun, and the densest and fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System.</seg>
<seg>It is sometimes referred to as the world, the Blue Planet, or by its Latin name, Terra.</seg>
tuv.seg: It is also the biggest of the Solar System's four planets.
Это также наибольшая из четырёх населенных планет солнечной Системы.

tuv.prop: <seg>It is also the largest of the Solar System's four terrestrial planets.</seg>
<seg>Earth formed approximately 4.54 billion years ago, and life appeared on its surface within one billion years.</seg>
tuv.seg: It is sometimes referred to as the world or by its Latin name, Terra.
Иногда именуется, как мир, Голубая планета, или его латинское название, Терра.

tuv.prop: <seg>It is sometimes referred to as the world, the Blue Planet, or by its Latin name, Terra.</seg>

<seg>Earth's biosphere then significantly altered the atmospheric and other basic physical conditions, which enabled the proliferation of organisms as well as the formation of the ozone layer, which together with Earth's magnetic field blocked harmful solar radiation, and permitted formerly ocean-confined life to move safely to land.</seg>
tuv.seg: Earth formed approximately 4.54 billion years ago, and life appeared on its surface within one billion years.
Земля образовалась примерно 4.54 миллиарда лет назад, и жизнь появилась на её поверхности в течение одного миллиарда лет.

tuv.prop: <seg>Earth formed approximately 4.54 billion years ago, and life appeared on its surface within one billion years.</seg>
<seg>Thephysical properties of the Earth, as well as its geological history and orbit, have allowed life to persist.</seg>
tuv.seg: Earth's biosphere then significantly altered the atmospheric and other basic physical conditions, which enabled the proliferation of organisms as well as the formation of the ozone layer, which together with Earth's magnetic field blocked harmful solar radiation, and permitted formerly ocean-confined life to move safely to land.

Биосфера Земли, то значительно изменили атмосферу и другие основные физические условия, которые позволили распространения организмов, а также формирование озонового слоя, который вместе с магнитным полем Земли заблокирован вредного солнечного излучения, и разрешенного ранее океанской жизни локализованным безопасно передвигаться на землю.

tuv.prop: <seg>Earth's biosphere then significantly altered the atmospheric and other basic physical conditions, which enabled the proliferation of organisms as well as the formation of the ozone layer, which together with Earth's magnetic field blocked harmful solar radiation, and permitted formerly ocean-confined life to move safely to land.</seg>
<seg>Estimates on how much longer the planet will be able to continue to support life range from 500 million years (myr), to as long as 2.3 billion years (byr).</seg>
tuv.seg: Thephysical properties of the Earth, as well as its geological history and orbit, have allowed life to persist.
То, что многие свойства Земли, а также ее геологической истории и орбиты, позволили жизни, сохранится.

tuv.prop: <seg>Thephysical properties of the Earth, as well as its geological history and orbit, have allowed life to persist.</seg>
<seg>Earth's lithosphere is divided into several rigid segments, or tectonic plates, that migrate across the surface over periods of many millions of years.</seg>
tuv.seg: Estimates on how much longer the planet will be able to continue to support life range from 500 million years (myr), to as long as 2.3 billion years (byr).
Оценки на сколько больше планета сможет продолжать поддерживать диапазон жизни от 500 миллионов лет (MYR), до тех пор, как 2,3 млрд лет (BYR).

tuv.prop: <seg>Estimates on how much longer the planet will be able to continue to support life range from 500 million years (myr), to as long as 2.3 billion years (byr).</seg>

<seg>About 71% of the surface is covered by salt water oceans, with the remainder consisting of continents and islands which together have many lakes and other sources of water that contribute to the hydrosphere.</seg>
tuv.seg: Earth's lithosphere is divided into several rigid segments, or tectonic plates, that migrate across the surface over periods of many millions of years.

tuv.prop: <seg>Earth's lithosphere is divided into several rigid segments, or tectonic plates, that migrate across the surface over periods of many millions of years.</seg>
<seg>Earth's poles are mostly covered with ice that is the solid ice of the Antarctic ice sheet and the sea ice that is the polar ice packs.</seg>
tuv.seg: About 71% of the surface is covered by salt water oceans, with the remainder consisting of continents and islands which together have many lakes and other sources of water that contribute to the hydrosphere.

tuv.prop: <seg>About 71% of the surface is covered by salt water oceans, with the remainder consisting of continents and islands which together have many lakes and other sources of water that contribute to the hydrosphere.</seg>
<seg>The planet's interior remains active, with a solid iron inner core, a liquid outer core that generates the magnetic field, and a thick layer of relatively solid mantle.</seg>
tuv.seg: Earth's poles are mostly covered with ice that is the solid ice of the Antarctic ice sheet and the sea ice that is the polar ice packs.

<seg>Earth gravitationally interacts with other objects in space, especially the Sun and the Moon.</seg>
tuv.seg: The planet's interior remains active, with a solid iron inner core, a liquid outer core that generates the magnetic field, and a thick layer of relatively solid mantle.

tuv.prop: <seg>The planet's interior remains active, with a solid iron inner core, a liquid outer core that generates the magnetic field, and a thick layer of relatively solid mantle.</seg>

<seg>During one orbit around the Sun, the Earth rotates about its own axis 366.26 times, creating 365.26 solar days, or one sidereal year.The Earth's axis of rotation is tilted 23.4° away from theperpendicular of its orbital plane, producing seasonal variations on the planet's surface with a period of one tropical year (365.24 solar days).</seg>
tuv.seg: Earth gravitationally interacts with other objects in space, especially the Sun and the Moon.

tuv.prop: <seg>Earth gravitationally interacts with other objects in space, especially the Sun and the Moon.</seg>
<seg>The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite.</seg>
tuv.seg: During one orbit around the Sun, the Earth rotates about its own axis 366.26 times, creating 365.26 solar days, or one sidereal year.The Earth's axis of rotation is tilted 23.4° away from theperpendicular of its orbital plane, producing seasonal variations on the planet's surface with a period of one tropical year (365.24 solar days).

tuv.prop: <seg>During one orbit around the Sun, the Earth rotates about its own axis 366.26 times, creating 365.26 solar days, or one sidereal year.The Earth's axis of rotation is tilted 23.4° away from theperpendicular of its orbital plane, producing seasonal variations on the planet's surface with a period of one tropical year (365.24 solar days).</seg>
<seg>It began orbiting the Earth about 4.53 billion years ago (bya).</seg>
tuv.seg: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite.

tuv.prop: <seg>The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite.</seg>
<seg>The Moon's gravitational interaction with Earth stimulates ocean tides, stabilizes the axial tilt, and gradually slows the planet's rotation.</seg>
tuv.seg: It began orbiting the Earth about 4.53 billion years ago (bya).

<seg>The planet is home to millions of species, including humans.</seg>

<seg>Both the mineral resources of the planet and the products of the biosphere contribute resources that are used to support a global human population.</seg>
tuv.seg: The planet is home to millions of species, including humans.

<seg>These inhabitants are grouped into about 200 independent sovereign states, which interact through diplomacy, travel, trade, and military action.</seg>

<seg>Human cultures have developed many views of the planet, including its personification as a planetary deity, its shape as flat, its position as the center of the universe, and in the modern Gaia Principle, as a single, self-regulating organism in its own right.</seg>
tuv.seg: These inhabitants are grouped into about 200 independent sovereign states, which interact through diplomacy, travel, trade, and military action.

<seg>The modern English noun earth developed from Middle English erthe (recorded in 1137), itself from Old English eorthe (dating from before 725), deriving from Proto-Germanic *erthō.</seg>
tuv.seg: Human cultures have developed many views of the planet, including its personification as a planetary deity, its shape as flat, its position as the center of the universe, and in the modern Gaia Principle, as a single, self-regulating organism in its own right.

<seg>Earth has cognates in all other Germanic languages, including Dutch aarde, German Erde, and Swedish, Norwegian, and Danish jord.</seg>
tuv.seg: The modern English noun earth developed from Middle English erthe (recorded in 1137), itself from Old English eorthe (dating from before 725), deriving from Proto-Germanic *erthō.

<seg>In general English usage, the name earth can be capitalized or spelled in lowercase interchangeably, either when used absolutely or prefixed with "the" (i.e. "Earth", "the Earth", "earth", or "the earth").</seg>
tuv.seg: The Earth is personified as a goddess in Germanic paganism (appearing as Jörð in Norse mythology, mother of the god Thor).

tuv.seg: In general English usage, the name earth can be capitalized or spelled in lowercase interchangeably, either when used absolutely or prefixed with "the" (i.e. "Earth", "the Earth", "earth", or "the earth").

tuv.prop: <seg>In general English usage, the name earth can be capitalized or spelled in lowercase interchangeably, either when used absolutely or prefixed with "the" (i.e. "Earth", "the Earth", "earth", or "the earth").</seg>
<seg>This is to distinguish it as a proper noun, distinct from the senses of the term as a mass noun or verb (e.g. referring to soil, the ground, earthing in the electrical sense, etc.).</seg>
tuv.seg: Many deliberately spell the name of the planet with a capital, both as "Earth" or "the Earth".

<seg>Oxford spelling recognizes the lowercase form as the most common, with the capitalized form as a variant of it.</seg>
tuv.seg: This is to distinguish it as a proper noun, distinct from the senses of the term as a mass noun or verb (e.g. referring to soil, the ground, earthing in the electrical sense, etc.).

<seg>Another common convention is to spell the name with a capital when occurring absolutely (e.g. Earth's atmosphere) and lowercase when preceded by "the" (e.g. the atmosphere of the earth).</seg>
tuv.seg: Oxford spelling recognizes the lowercase form as the most common, with the capitalized form as a variant of it.

tuv.prop: <seg>Oxford spelling recognizes the lowercase form as the most common, with the capitalized form as a variant of it.</seg>
<seg>The term almost exclusively exists in lowercase when appearing in common phrases, even without "the" preceding it (e.g. "It does not cost the earth.", "What on earth are you doing?").</seg>

tuv.prop: <seg>Organisms continuously evolve, taking on new forms or going extinct in response to an ever-changing planet.</seg>

<seg>The biosphere, in turn, has had a significant effect on the atmosphere and other abiotic conditions on the planet, such as the formation of the ozone layer, the proliferation of oxygen, and the creation of soil.</seg>
